section.title: Introduction
section.para: IO stream types are very useful for a variety of purposes. However, C++11 added a number of features to C++ and the standard library that were never fully integrated into some of these classes. This proposal is an attempt to align the stream classes to more modern techniques and uses.

section.title: Proposals and Justifications
section.para: This proposal suggests a plethora of fixes to various stream classes:

listitem.para: The ability to use all streams with range-based for, in a flexible and easy-to-use way.
Movement of basic_string objects into and out of stringstreams.
More initializers for stringstreams. Specifically, initialization by iterator ranges and by charT arrays with explicit sizes.

section.title: Range Adapters for Streams
section.para: This involves the creation of a number of non-member functions which return iterator ranges from basic_istreams. In the absence of a concrete range proposal, this will instead focus on producing objects which can be used in range-based for loops. The general idea is to mirror the existing stream iterator classes. Thus, a range will simply be a pair of appropriate iterators.
The range will be exposed by a series of functions. They will be:

The return value of these functions will be a class for which begin and end can be called. This can be through direct member functions or specializations/overloads of std::begin/std::end, as appropriate. These functions will return the start and end of the appropriate iterator range. istream_range's return value will yield std::istream_iterator<T> iterators. And so forth.

The returned class will be copy/move constructible and assignable. It will have all of the features of istream_iterator, including the same set of typedefs. If T is a literal type, then the class will have a constexpr constructor and a trivial copy constructor and destructor.

section.title: Move Support for Stringstreams
section.para: Consider a common use case of ostringstream: building a string in memory based on a successive series of formatting operations:
Once the string has been built in the stream, it must be stored into a std::string:
Currently, this is a string copy operation. There is no need for this, especially if out_data is going to be destroyed immediately afterwards. Consider a function of the form:

Move support was added into C++11 to avoid precisely this sort of copying. If that were a std::string instead of a std::ostringstream, this would not be a problem. The return value would be move-constructed, and thus no copying would be needed.

Similarly, it is sometimes the case that the user finds themselves with a string that they need to perform input stream operations on. Perhaps they have some integers stored in a simple format that an std::istringstream would be appropriate for. Consider this code:

This performs two copies of the string data. First, from_c is copied into a std::string temporary. Then it is copied into its final destination in the istringstream. There is no need for this; one copy may be sufficient. The problem is that istringstream's constructor does not take an rvalue reference to a string.

To resolve these issues, this proposal will allow the basic_stringbuf and basic_stringstream classes to take basic_string classes by rvalue reference. They will have a constructor overload that does this, as well as a str() overload that takes the input value by rvalue reference.

Additionally, there will be a new function added, move_str, which returns a basic_string by value. This function will leave the stream or buffer in the standard moved-from state: valid but unspecified.

Note that this allows some leeway for implementations here. Implementations are not required to adopt the string's memory, or to return that memory when requested. They are simply permitted to do so, as with any other move operations. Unless the buffer is implemented in terms of basic_string, there would be no way to adopt that memory without the buffer having direct knowledge of the internal working of the basic_string class. So implementations will still have the freedom not to implement direct move support. But they would have the ability to do so if they wish.

section.title: Allocator Support for Stringstreams
section.para: C++11 added stateful allocators to the standard library containers. All of those containers already had constructors that took allocators, so few changes to the interface of those containers were necessary.

The stringstream classes permit the use of allocators. But they don't actually take allocator instances as parameters, which makes using allocators that have state pretty much impossible. They also don't have a get_allocator function. They also lack the ability to work with basic_string objects that use different allocator types from the stream class itself.
This will correct all of these issues. Specifically, there will be:

listitem.para: A constructor that takes an allocator instance (and the openmode flags).

A template constructor that takes a const basic_string &, with the basic_string's allocator being the template parameter. It will also take an optional allocator instance, to be default constructed when not specified.

note.para: There will not be a comparable version for basic_string &&. In order to move, the allocator types must be the same. Technically, one could perform a compile-time check to see if the allocator types are equality comparable, then do a runtime test to see if they're equal and only copy if they compare equal. However, requiring the same allocator types for movement is consistent with all existing standard containers.

listitem.para: A modification to the behavior of the constructor that takes a const basic_string & that uses the same allocator type as the container. In such a case, the allocator instance used by the stream/buf will be copied from the basic_string's allocator.

A modification to the behavior of the constructor that takes a basic_string && (added per the above). The allocator instance used by the stream/buf will be move-constructed from the basic_string's allocator.
A get_allocator function that returns the current allocator object.

A template overload of str that takes a const basic_string &, with the basic_string's allocator being the template parameter. It will also take an optional allocator instance, to be default constructed when not specified. The currently used allocator will be replaced by the given one.

A template overload of str. The return value is a basic_string, with the allocator type being the template parameter. This function will take an optional allocator instance argument, of the template parameter's type. This allocator instance will be used in the construction of the basic_string return value.
The moving move_str member function (added per the above) will use the move the current allocator instance into the basic_string.

section.title: Stringstream Initializers
section.para: At present, there is only one way to initialize stringstreams: with a basic_string. So if one has a string literal, this involves an additional copy of the string. While the move support added above will help cover that circumstance (though small string optimization can impact this), it would be better still to make it possible to initialize stringstreams in two other ways.

It should be possible to initialize a stringstream via an iterator pair (with an optional allocator), as well as via a null-terminated const CharT *. It can also take the string by the new string_view class, in order to improve interoperability. For the sake of consistency, there should also be an overload for a const CharT * + a length, even though string_view should cover that scenario adequately.
There should also be appropriate str overloads to do all of the above as well.

section.title: Impact on the Standard
section.para: These changes should all be completely backwards compatible. As for the ABI, this should not modify any of the existing functions of these classes. It will add new overloads that will be called in different situations, and the specific overload called by existing code may change. However, it will not change the meaning or intent of such code.

section.para: These specifications are written against section N3690, the C++14 CD.
In section 24.3, add the following after the stream iterators, but before the range accessors:
In section 24.6, add the following sections after 24.6.4:

blockquote.programlisting: template<class T, class Distance = std::ptrdiff_t, class CharT = char, class Traits = std::char_traits<CharT>> /*unspecified*/ istream_range(std::basic_istream<CharT, Traits> &stream);
blockquote.para: Returns: An object which is CopyConstrctible and DefaultConstructible. It will have a member function named begin which takes no parameters and returns an istream_iterator<T, CharT, Traits, Distance> that is constructed from stream. It will have a member function named end, which takes no parameters and returns a default-constructed istream_iterator<T, CharT, Traits, Distance>.

The return value's type will have public member typedefs char_type, traits_type, and istream_type. These will be taken from the istream_iterator that the begin and end functions will return. The type will also have a public member typedef iterator_type, which is istream_iterator<T, CharT, Traits, Distance>.
If T is a literal type, then the type of the return value will have the copy constructor and destructor be trivial.
blockquote.programlisting: template<class Distance = std::ptrdiff_t, class CharT = char, class Traits = std::char_traits<CharT>> /*unspecified*/ istreambuf_range(std::basic_istream<CharT, Traits> &stream) noexcept;
blockquote.para: Returns: An object which is CopyConstrctible and DefaultConstructible. It will have a member function named begin which takes no parameters and returns an istreambuf_iterator<CharT, Traits, Distance> that is constructed from stream. It will have a member function named end, which takes no parameters and returns a default-constructed istreambuf_iterator<CharT, Traits, Distance>.

The return value's type will have public member typedefs char_type, traits_type, and istream_type. These will be taken from the istreambuf_iterator that the begin and end functions will return. The type will also have a public member typedef iterator_type, which is istreambuf_iterator<T, CharT, Traits, Distance>.
The copy constructor and destructor will be trivial.

blockquote.para: Effects: Constructs an object of class basic_stringbuf, initializing the base class with basic_streambuf() (27.6.3.1), and initializing mode with which. Then calls str(move(s)).

section.para: In section 27.8.2.3, [stringbuf.members], add the following declarations:

blockquote.para: Effects: Copies or moves the content of s into the basic_stringbuf underlying character sequence and initializes the input and output sequences according to mode.
Postconditions: s is left in a valid-but-unspecified state.

If mode & ios_base::out is true, pbase() points to the first underlying character and epptr() >= pbase() + s.size() holds; in addition, if mode & ios_base::ate is true, pptr() == pbase() + s.size() holds, otherwise pptr() == pbase() is true. If mode & ios_base::in is true, eback() points to the first underlying character, and both gptr() == eback() and egptr() == eback() + s.size() hold.

Returns: Returns: A basic_string object whose content is equal to the basic_stringbuf underlying character sequence. If the basic_stringbuf was created only in input mode, the resultant basic_string contains the character sequence in the range [eback(),egptr()). If the basic_stringbuf was created with which & ios_base::out being true then, the resultant basic_string contains the character sequence in the range [pbase(),high_mark), where high_mark represents the position one past the highest initialized character in the buffer. Characters can be initialized by writing to the stream, by constructing the basic_stringbuf with a basic_string, or by calling the str(basic_string) member function. In the case of calling the str(basic_string) member function, all characters initialized prior to the call are now considered uninitialized (except for those characters re-initialized by the new basic_string). Otherwise the basic_stringbuf has been created in neither input nor output mode and a zero length basic_string is returned.
